bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1941

div1.p: Kean laments that the Ames family is trying to get Roger Post Ames included in the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor. He also discusses Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1941
div1.opener:
Dr. Philip S. Hench
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Monday
May 5/41
My dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Your special delivery letter of May
2nd arrived the next morning and was read
with much interest, and admiration
of your energy and zeal. I will try
to have every thing ready for you
on Thursday afternoon when you
arrive. Mrs Franck from the Mil-
Surgeon's Office can come and will
be here - a sensible middle aged
woman not very quick as a Stenog,
but reliable, and will be satis-
factory. I much prefer to finish
up Thursday evening and if I
am well will enjoy it. Will plan
for you to take dinner here, and
AC
K
2
Mrs. Franck also, so we can keep
right on. My house-boy goes to
hospital that day but we will
not starve. I hope you will be
able to meet Gen. Ireland while
you are here. We can get the
address of Mrs. Roger Post Ames
from Senator Shephards Office.
One of Dr Carroll's sons is here
in the Treasury. Gen. Ireland
has been on his trail & can tell
us how to find him.
I dont think that Mrs. Ames will
have any thing of interest. She has
been trying to get Ames' name put
on the Y. F. Roll of Honor, so she will
get a pension and has prepared a
very clever case in legal style. Convin-
cing to those who do not know the
inside facts. Sen. Shephard, who
3
died recently, was Chairman of the
Senate Military Committee and
I think got a favorable report
from it but did not win over
the House mil. Comtee

I have not talked with Gen Ireland
about a memorial at Camp Lazear
Perhaps you will have a chance.
Suppose I get him to take lunch
with us at the Army & Navy Club
on Friday, and you can got to the
Signal Corps and Q. M. Gen's Office
after lunch. I dont think you can
get get any thing there to pay for the
effort however. The plans of those
shacks at Camp Lazear were too
informal to be preserved all these
years and being built with Cuban
funds would not come to Washington
unless in some medical document.

A more urgent question than the
location of that stovepipe hole is
where you will find a room on the
night of Thursday 8th, as the hotels
in Wash. have been crowded to the
doors since before Easter and they
ceased to answer letters of inquiry.
So I would be surprised if you have
any success in your request to the
Mayflower. The Army & Navy Club
which usually can find a room for
guests with cards sent out a circular
that for the present they would
restrict the rooms to members who
were non-resident. But on talking
to the office I was told that if on
Tuesday morning there was a
room to spare I could get it
for you, and in any event they
have an arrangement with near-
by hotels by which they could secure
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
a room. So if you do not get ac-
commodation at the Mayflower send
me a wire and I will take it up
with the Club Thursday morning.

Since writing the above I
have gotten in touch with General
Ireland who has been away for
a week. He will get in touch with
young Carroll and will make inqui-
ries about the Gen. Staff map collec-
tion. I have been greatly interested
in the Hemmeter articles and letters
that you would had mimeographed-
and have made notes on the margin
as you requested.
